resources.string: You\'ll begin the program with a full-body training opens a new window. Split,meaning you\'ll train all major bodyparts in each workout(as oppopsed to \"splitting up\" your training). Train Three days this first week , performing just one exercise per bodypart in each session. It\'s important that you have a day of rest between each workout to allow your body to recover; this makes training Monday, Wednesday and Friday- with Saturday and Sunday being rest days- a good approach.

The exercise listed in Week 1 are a collection of basic moves that are a collection of basic moves that , while also used by advanced lifters, we feel are suitable for beginners as well. Notice we\'re not starting you off with only machine exercises; handfull of free-weight movements are present right off the bat .Reason being,these are the exercises you need to master for long-terms gains in muscular size and strength .So you may as well start learning them now. Carefully read all exercise descriptions before attempting them yourself.

You\'re only week into the program, yet you\'ll begin to train different bodyparts on different days with a two-day training split Opens a window. (meaning the entire body is trained over the course of two days, rather than one as in the first week); the split include two upper-body days(Monday and Thursday) and two lower body days(Tuesday and Friday), and each bodypart is trained twice . Wednesday,Saturday and Sunday will be your recovery days.

In the Third week of the program we step it up to a Three-day training split: Train all \"pushing\" bodyparts (Chest,shoulders,triceps) on Day1; and abs on Day 2; and work your lower body (quads , glutes,hamstring,calves ) on Day 3. As in week 2, you train twice each body part twice a week, so you\'ll hit the gym six days this week.

In the fourth and final week of the program , you\'ll train four days in a four-way split that hits each body part just once (except calves and abs,which are each trained twice). Four-day splits are commonly among expercied lifters because they involve training fewer bodypart(typically 2-3) per workout, which gives each muscle group ample attention and allows you to train with higher volume.

Monday: Chest / Triceps 

 Tuesday: Back / Biceps 

 Wednesday : Shoulder /Traps 

 Thursday: Thigh / Calves / Abs 

 Friday : Chest / Triceps 

 Saturday: Back /Biceps 

 Sunday: Shoulder / Traps

By doing 8-12 repititions for each set , you\'ll stimulate maximum hypertrophy. However,this is based on the average person. Every person responds to weightlifting differently , some better, some worse. Simply try this routine and then adjust it according to your own unique body type. \n\n
Warm-ups sets require at least 12 repetitions depending on the size of the muscle you are using.It is very important to warm-up and stretch the muscle group that you\'ll be targeting before you start your routine . Failure to warm-up and stretch properly before workouts can result in sever injury.

Unfortunately, the longer you weight lift, the slower your gain will be . Beginners get \"newbie gains\" when they first weight train . These gains will typically last about 2-3 months. Newbie gains include rapid muscle gains and a rapid increase in strength. \n\n if one consumes suffecient food/proteins and has enough active rest,then they can expect to gain at least 5-10 pounds of muscle per month in the \"newbie gain\" stage. The amount of muscle gained will vary among different body types. The muscle gained during this stage is permanent.

Week 1: Chest , Back , Shoulders , Legs , Biceps , Triceps 

 Week 3: Shoulder , Back , Chest , Legs , Triceps , Biceps

Day 1: Chest,Shoulders and Triceps 

 Day 2: Back and Biceps

 Day 3: Legs

 Day 4: Chest,Shoulders and Triceps

 Day 5: Back and Bis

 Day 6: Shoulders and Arms

 Day 6: Rest
